content.content: 10MM $UNI (~$60MM) are currently necessary to submit a formal proposal.  Even Andre Cronje is having trouble getting enough $UNI delegated:   twitter.com    Andre Cronje (AndreCronjeTech)  It seems there is some misunderstanding. I don't actually want to be a delegate. I just think its next to impossible to actually collect 10M worth of delegate votes to actually make a proposal. I've been spamming the whole day and have 385.7K UNI  11:39 AM - 19 Sep 2020     93          5            I propose that Uniswap adopt Compound’s Autonomous Proposals [1] to help alleviate this problem:   twitter.com    devops199fan 🔪📜😅 (devops199fan)  @aliatiia_ @UniswapProtocol 💯  @UniswapProtocol should also adopt @compoundfinance's Autonomous Proposals 🤖  it effectively reduces the barrier to creating formal proposals by letting community members pool voting power 💪  left a comment on the thread too 😁  h/t @cjliu49   https://t.co/VTluRgSiGw  8:24 PM - 18 Sep 2020     17          1            [1] https://medium.com/compound-finance/compound-autonomous-proposals-354e7a2ad6b7
content.GPT-summary: The author of the post is proposing that Uniswap adopt Compound's Autonomous Proposals to help alleviate the problem of collecting enough delegate votes to make a proposal. A third party is giving constructive criticism of the proposal and suggesting that the author should explain the proposal in more detail. Another third party is extending to the proposal and suggesting that Uniswap should also adopt Compound's Autonomous Proposals. The post can also be categorized as advertising the proposal.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal
3rd party or author is advertising proposal

content.content: Great idea. I’m seeing a lot of proposals. Is there a due process for having these actually gain traction and become actionable processes? Is the first step to enable delegates the ability to create proposals?
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party or author is advertising proposal

content.content: There’s nothing that needs to be done for people to start using these immediately. It doesn’t require a governance proposal. Anyone who wants to submit one can just deploy this contract and swap out the token + governance address for UNI and UniswapGovernance   github.com   compound-finance/autonomous-proposals/blob/master/contracts/CrowdProposalFactory.sol#L26   /// @notice An event emitted when a crowd proposal is created event CrowdProposalCreated(address indexed proposal, address indexed author, address[] targets, uint[] values, string[] signatures, bytes[] calldatas, string description);   /**  * @notice Construct a proposal factory for crowd proposals  * @param comp_ `COMP` token contract address  * @param governor_ Compound protocol `GovernorAlpha` contract address  * @param compStakeAmount_ The minimum amount of Comp tokes required for creation of a crowd proposal  */ constructor(address comp_,             address governor_,             uint compStakeAmount_) public {     comp = comp_;     governor = governor_;     compStakeAmount = compStakeAmount_; }  /** * @notice Create a new crowd proposal * @notice Call `Comp.approve(factory_address, compStakeAmount)` before calling this method
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: i submitted 1k votes to myself is this good? I thought i could submit proposals and vote…Damn poor andre cronje…
Does Uniswap’s main voting UI pick these up the way that Compound’s does? Or does the creator need to figure out UI & publicity?
